awd_titl_txt: NeTS: Small: Designing Agile and Scalable Self-Healing Functionalities for Ultra Dense Future Cellular Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Cellular networks are subject to cell outages of several types.  Complete outages are often caused by equipment malfunctions; partial outages or degraded performances are often caused by parameter mis-configurations. Outage rates are proportional to cell density and base station complexity. Both of these factors have been consistently on rise from 1G to 4G. Current semi-automated approaches to cell outage management have proven inadequate and highly inefficient even for today's network, and are surely unfeasible for future cellular networks marked by ultra-dense cell deployment and mounting complexity. If no intervening measures are taken, cell outage management may become a primary challenge for future cellular networks, such as 5G. To remedy this, this project will develop an Advance Cell Outage Management (ACOM) framework for fully automating cell outage detection and compensation in future ultra-dense, heterogeneous cellular networks. ACOM will be built by developing and integrating three novel solutions: 1) Autonomous Macro Cell Outage Detection and root cause analysis (MOD); 2) Autonomous Small Cell Outage Detection and root cause analysis (SOD); and 3) Autonomous Heterogeneous Cell Outage Compensation (HOC). In ACOM, the outage detected and diagnosed by MOD and SOD will be exploited by the optimization process in HOC to transform future ultra-dense, heterogeneous cellular deployments into fully self-healing systems. 

Key distinct features of ACOM will include agility, stability and flexibility to accommodate varying user densities, cell sizes, and radio channel conditions, and ultra-dense deployments of small cells. The proposed plan lies at the nexus of profiling, anomaly detection, prediction, sparse matrix completions, multidimensional scaling, and dynamics handling. It employs machine learning, optimization, and game theory. Project outcomes will be validated using data from real network data while leveraging a full scale outdoor 5G testbed. If successful, this project is certain to make strong impact on all aspects of evolving digital society that count on reliability of cellular networks. Another key impact of this project is that it offers strong workforce training in a highly sought-after multi-disciplinary skill set needed to conduct proposed research, while ensuring participation of women and other underrepresented groups, and K-12 outreach. The project will also leverage collaboration with national and international stake holders in the cellular ecosystem to maximize its impact on standardization.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
Wireless cellular networks are subject to cell outages because of misconfigurations of any few of the thousands of configuration parameters each cell contains.  Outages also happen due to software or hardware failures within a cell. Such outages become more difficult to manage as the cell density continues to grow in emerging networks e.g. from 4G to 5G and beyond.   In current cellular networks, expensive drive tests or hardware fault alarms are employed for detecting cell outages. This process takes hours to days to detect an alarm-less outage (or sleeping cell).  Once detected, transitory cell outage compensation in the affected area is accomplished with makeshift cell-on-wheel or by manually adjusting the parameters of neighboring cells. Such semi-manual approach to cell outage management have proven inadequate and highly inefficient even for today’s networks. This approach will cease to be sustainable for future cellular networks marked by ultra-dense cell deployment and mounting operational complexity. Besides this current semi-manual approach is a major hurdle in achieving ultra-reliable low latency communications in emerging networks. The goal of this project has been to solve this problem by developing automated outage detection and compensation solutions thereby enabling self-healing capabilities in emerging and future networks. The project has exceeded expected targets in achieving this ambitious goal by producing a large set of innovative and interoperable solutions that can enable AI powered self-healing capabilities in emerging networks. The intellectual outcomes of the project that together enable aforementioned self-healing capabilities include: 1) Methods to overcome shortage of training data to train AI based coverage estimation models;  2 ) Methods to overcome errors in estimated coverage caused by user positioning and measurement quantization errors in user reported measurements of coverage; 3)  AI based solution to detect outages autonomously from sparse and noisy user reported measurements instead of relying on drive tests; 4) AI based solution to detect outages in small cells and macro cells; 5 ) Entropy Field Decomposition based solution to detect outages in high fading environments such as millimeter wave cells; 6) AI based solution to diagnose root cause of the outages using incomplete training data; 7) Solution to autonomously compensate for detected outages through UAV based temporary cell deployments; 8) Solutions to autonomously compensate outages through optimization of soft and hard parameters of neighboring cells 9)AI based solution to predict certain cell outages before they happen and thus enable proactive maintenance and increase network reliability to an ultra-high level that is not possible with any state of the art reactive outage detection solution;10) A complete self-healing framework to detect most outages autonomously and compensate them seamlessly within seconds without human intervention.

In terms of broader impact, the innovative solutions produced in this project have potential to transform the way cellular networks are currently operated and maintained to reduce OPEX substantially and increase the network reliability significantly. This has broader impact beyond the technology, as emerging digital society counts more and more on high network reliability. For example, current drive test-based approach takes days and tens of thousands of dollars of effort and equipment to detect an outage. The solutions produced in this project have potential to enable outage detection and compensation in seconds with negligible cost.  

To accelerate its broader impact the outcomes of the project have been disseminated widely to industry stake holders and academic community through publication of twenty-two Journal papers, thirteen conference proceeding papers, one book chapter and thirteen oral presentations at international conferences. Project has also produced three MS thesis and two  PhD thesis. Project outcomes have also been disseminated through several tutorials and keynotes at international conferences. For impact on standardization and industry panel talks/keynotes were given at industry forums to share project outcomes directly with pertinent industry stakeholders. Project resulted in post graduate level training of four engineers, including two female engineers in domain of AI and wireless. One female PhD student won dissertation excellence award at the University of Oklahoma for her research contributions based on this project work. All project students are already using their training to directly impact the industry while being employed with top labs and high-tech employers in the nation e.g (Microsoft,  Ericsson-USA, AT&T labs). Project also trained three minority K-12 students two of which published peer reviewed papers and all three have taken up STEM as a career. More than a dozen industry stakeholders that have benefitted directly (e.g., through hiring of project GRAs as internee or employee) or indirectly (e.g., by collaborating with PI lab or inviting PI to share project outcomes). A tutorial and extensive survey paper produced by the project has become foundational reference material on the topic of self-healing in emerging networks. Project has resulted in one granted patent. Combined project outcomes have led to a start-up that is likely to secure seed funding to further develop and commercialize project outcomes.


Last Modified: 04/09/2022
Modified by: Ali Imran
